Notes: On 9 may 2022, some jurisdictions have no covid-related health measures in schools However, some provinces and territories continue to require masks and other covid-related health measures in schools â e.g., some Atlantic provinces and Quebec. Some post-secondary institutions are offering classes and exams online or have implemented vaccine mandates for students and staff to enter campus. In most cases, these decisions are set by individual post-secondary institutions rather than dictated or guided by governments. However, at Memorial University of Newfoundland (MUN), Newfoundland and Labradorâs (NLâs) only university and largest post-secondary institution: âStudents, staff and faculty at Memorial must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 or have an approved accommodation. This requirement aligns with the Government of Newfoundland and Labradorâs Mandatory Vaccination Policy and is subject to change based on changes to the government policy.â In sum, 1T fits vaccinated students with mask and other covid-related health measures still applicable in schools in some jurisdictions and 2T fits for unvaccinated students, who cannot enter the post-secondary MUN campus because MUN âaligns with the Government of Newfoundland and Labradorâs Mandatory Vaccination Policyâ. See governments of PEI, NL, Quebec, MUN websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220502105615/https://www.princeedwardisland.ca/en/information/health-and-wellness/moving-on-transition-plan-to-living-with-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20220502105936/https://www.quebec.ca/en/health/health-issues/a-z/2019-coronavirus/mask-or-face-covering/wearing-a-face-covering-in-public-settings-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20220510021035/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/schools-children/schools/masks/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220510021117/https://www.mun.ca/covid19/news.php?id=14864&type=news

On 16 may 2022, some jurisdictions have no covid-related health measures in schools. However, some provinces and territories continue to require masks and other covid-related health measures in schools â e.g., some Atlantic provinces. Some post-secondary institutions are offering classes and exams online or have implemented vaccine mandates for students and staff to enter campus. In most cases, these decisions are set by individual post-secondary institutions rather than dictated or guided by governments. However, at Memorial University of Newfoundland (MUN), Newfoundland and Labradorâs (NLâs) only university and largest post-secondary institution: âStudents, staff and faculty at Memorial must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 or have an approved accommodation. This requirement aligns with the Government of Newfoundland and Labradorâs Mandatory Vaccination Policy and is subject to change based on changes to the government policy.â In sum, 1T fits vaccinated students with mask and other covid-related health measures still applicable in schools in some jurisdictions and 2T fits for unvaccinated students, who cannot enter the post-secondary MUN campus because MUN âaligns with the Government of Newfoundland and Labradorâs Mandatory Vaccination Policyâ. See government of PEI, CTV news, MUN websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220516145709/https://atlantic.ctvnews.ca/newfoundland-and-labrador-to-drop-mandatory-masking-in-schools-on-may-24-1.5901841  https://web.archive.org/web/20220516145945/https://www.princeedwardisland.ca/en/information/health-and-wellness/moving-on-transition-plan-to-living-with-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20220516150258/https://www.mun.ca/covid19/news.php?id=14864&type=news

On 23 may 2022, some provinces are approaching the end of mandates requiring masks and other covid-related health measures in elementary and secondary schools. Some post-secondary institutions are offering classes and exams online or have implemented vaccine mandates for students and staff to enter campus. In most cases, these decisions are set by individual post-secondary institutions rather than dictated or guided by governments. However, at Memorial University of Newfoundland (MUN), Newfoundland and Labradorâs (NLâs) only university and largest post-secondary institution: âStudents, staff and faculty at Memorial must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 or have an approved accommodation. This requirement aligns with the Government of Newfoundland and Labradorâs Mandatory Vaccination Policy and is subject to change based on changes to the government policy.â In sum, 1T fits vaccinated students with mask and other covid-related health measures still applicable in schools in some jurisdictions and 2T fits for unvaccinated students, who cannot enter the post-secondary MUN campus because MUN âaligns with the Government of Newfoundland and Labradorâs Mandatory Vaccination Policyâ. See governments of NL and PEI, CTV news, MUN websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220522170646/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/schools-children/schools/masks/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220522164219/https://www.princeedwardisland.ca/en/information/health-and-wellness/moving-on-transition-plan-to-living-with-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20220516145709/https://atlantic.ctvnews.ca/newfoundland-and-labrador-to-drop-mandatory-masking-in-schools-on-may-24-1.5901841  https://web.archive.org/web/20220516150258/https://www.mun.ca/covid19/news.php?id=14864&type=news

On 24 may 2022, the last four jurisdictions â Prince Edward Island, Nova Scotia, Newfoundland and Labrador, Yukon â previously requiring masks in elementary and secondary schools end their mandates â âall provinces in Canada have removed mask mandates in schoolsâ. Some post-secondary institutions are requiring masks on campus, offering classes and exams online and/or have implemented vaccine mandates for students and staff to enter campus. In most cases, these decisions are set by individual post-secondary institutions rather than dictated or guided by governments. However, at Memorial University of Newfoundland (MUN), Newfoundland and Labradorâs (NLâs) only university and largest post-secondary institution: âStudents, staff and faculty at Memorial must be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 or have an approved accommodation. This requirement aligns with the Government of Newfoundland and Labradorâs Mandatory Vaccination Policy and is subject to change based on changes to the government policy.â In sum, 0 fits vaccinated students with mask and other covid-related health measures no longer applicable in schools and 2T fits for unvaccinated students, who cannot enter the post-secondary MUN campus because MUN âaligns with the Government of Newfoundland and Labradorâs Mandatory Vaccination Policyâ. See governments of NS, Yukon and PEI, CTV news, MUN websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220527103208/https://atlantic.ctvnews.ca/mask-mandates-end-in-all-atlantic-canadian-schools-but-health-officials-still-recommend-their-use-1.5916436  https://web.archive.org/web/20220527103515/https://novascotia.ca/news/release/?id=20220519001  https://web.archive.org/web/20220522164219/https://www.princeedwardisland.ca/en/information/health-and-wellness/moving-on-transition-plan-to-living-with-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20220530171554/https://yukon.ca/en/health-and-wellness/covid-19-information/k-12-school-guidelines-2021-22-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20220516150258/https://www.mun.ca/covid19/news.php?id=14864&type=news

On 30 may 2022, âall provinces in Canada have removed their school mask mandatesâ. Some post-secondary institutions are requiring masks on campus, offering classes and exams online and/or have implemented vaccine mandates for students and staff to enter campus. In most cases, these decisions are set by individual post-secondary institutions rather than dictated or guided by governments. However, at Memorial University of Newfoundland (MUN), Newfoundland and Labradorâs (NLâs) only university and largest post-secondary institution: âprocedure for vaccine requirementâ remains in force until 1 June. âMemorial continues to follow the most up-to-date advice provided by the Government of Newfoundland and Labradorâ. In sum, 0 fits vaccinated students with mask and other covid-related health measures no longer applicable in schools and 2T fits for unvaccinated students, who cannot enter the post-secondary MUN campus because MUN âcontinues to follow the most up-to-date advice provided by the Government of Newfoundland and Labradorâ. See Globe and Mail newspaper and MUN websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220530171144/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-nova-scotia-to-lift-its-covid-19-mask-mandate-for-provinces-public/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220530170157/https://www.mun.ca/covid19/

On 1 june 2022, âall provinces in Canada have removed their school mask mandatesâ. Some post-secondary institutions are requiring masks on campus, offering classes and exams online and/or have implemented vaccine mandates for students and staff to enter campus. However, these decisions are set by individual post-secondary institutions rather than dictated or guided by governments. At Memorial University of Newfoundland (MUN), Newfoundland and Labradorâs (NLâs) only university and largest post-secondary institution: âMemorial suspended the requirement for masks on all campuses on June 1â¦ Memorial's procedure for vaccine requirement suspended on June 1 at 12:01 a.m. in alignment with the suspension of the NL Public Sector Policy.â In sum, 0 fits vaccinated students with mask and other covid-related health measures no longer applicable in schools at any level and 0 now fits for unvaccinated students, who can now enter the post-secondary MUN campus âin alignment with the suspension of the [government of NL] Public Sector Policyâ. On 9 may 2022 the Chief Public Health Officer of Canada continues to recommend: âStaying home and keeping away from others if you test positive or are experiencing any symptoms, even if mildâ. The  âany symptoms, even if mildâ component of this recommendation is broader and more prescriptive than previous advice at the end of 2021: âstay at home when you're sick â¦ Be prepared to stay at home if you have symptomsâ. Some jurisdictions are not following the national governmentâs recommendation and have ended isolation rules for covid-positive patients. However, the Chief Public Health Officer of Canadaâs recommendation is publicly available for all Canadians. See government of Canada and CBC news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220509132302/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/news/2020/07/information-and-resources-on-covid-19-epidemiology-and-reducing-your-risks-for-infection-and-spreading-the-virus.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220509133204/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/manitoba-covid-19-isolation-requirement-personal-care-home-1.6376095

On 16 may 2022, the government of Canada continues ârequiring full vaccination for Canadians boarding a commercial plane or train for travel to domestic and international destinationsâ. A prominent professor of medicine urges the government to âreconsider [as] The justification behind vaccine mandates is that they help prevent transmission. But this does not seem to be the case any longer, with the Omicron variantâ. He cites equity grounds and several other arguments against the national governmentâs vaccine mandate for domestic air and rail travelers. See Globe and Mail newspaper, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220514162340/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/article-the-logic-behind-vaccine-mandates-for-travellers-no-longer-holds/

On 23 may 2022, the government of Canada âcontinues to ban unvaccinated people from domestic plane and train travelâ. The editorial board of a leading newspaper argues that the government âneeds to explain whyâ. See Government of Canada as well as Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220519151106/https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions/domestic-travel  https://web.archive.org/web/20220521155247/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/opinion/editorials/article-is-it-time-to-end-canadas-last-remaining-covid-travel-restrictions/

On 11 may 2022, Canada remains open to entry by non-citizens, but only those who meet the following requirements: âyou must qualify as a fully vaccinated traveller to enter Canada, unless you have a job in 1 of the following categories: Agricultural or food processing worker; Marine crew member; Make medical deliveries; Work with medical equipment or devicesâ. In sum, the Canadian border is closed to all unvaccinated, non-essential foreign visitors. The Canadian border is open to fully vaccinated foreign visitors subject to screening requirements. See Government of Canada website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220511215638/https://travel.gc.ca/travel-covid/travel-restrictions/visitors-workers-students

On 9 may 2022, the government of Canada continues with a ânational public education campaign that provides Canadians with evidence-based information on COVID-19, and encourages behaviours that protect individuals and our communities. This campaign includes advertising, partnerships, social marketing, social media posts, information resources, targeted outreach to at-risk populations.â However, some sub-national governments have shifted to a âliving with covidâ approach with lower-profile and/or less frequent public communication. See Government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220508140122/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/canadas-reponse.html

This campaign includes advertising, partnerships, social marketing, social media posts, information resources, targeted outreach to at-risk populations.â Note that some sub-national governments have shifted to a âliving with covidâ approach with lower-profile and/or less frequent public communication emphasizing individual risk management. On 9 may 2022, the policy intent of some jurisdictions continues to   be to supplement polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of symptomatic cases with mass availability of lateral flow and other rapid tests to asymptomatic individuals. However, in most parts of Canada, the caseload wave is frustrating efforts to achieve testing aspirations. E.g., in Canadaâs most populous province: âPCR testing is limited to certain groups. The scientific director of Ontarioâs panel of COVID-19 advisers has said multiplying the daily case count by 20 would give a more accurate picture.â See Government of Canada as well as Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220508140504/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-ontario-reports-24-new-covid-19-deaths-hospitalizations-drop/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220508140846/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html

On 16 may 2022, the policy intent of some jurisdictions continues to   be to supplement polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of symptomatic cases with mass availability of lateral flow and other rapid tests to asymptomatic individuals. However, in most parts of Canada, the caseload wave is frustrating efforts to achieve testing aspirations. A prominent health policy reporter states: âTo date, there have been 3.8 million recorded cases in Canada (the true number is certainly much higher because weâve largely given up on testing.)â See Government of Canada as well as Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220515162357/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220514165219/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-canada-40000-covid-19-deaths/

On 23 may 2022, the policy intent of some jurisdictions continues to   be to supplement polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of symptomatic cases with mass availability of lateral flow rapid tests to asymptomatic individuals. However, in most parts of Canada, the caseload wave is frustrating efforts to achieve testing aspirations. In Canadaâs most populous province: âPublic Health Ontario noted that testing eligibility is currently restricted to high-risk populations â¦Ontario reported 1,412 new infections of COVID-19 Friday [out of a total population of almost 15 million], although PCR testing is limited to certain groups. The scientific director of Ontarioâs panel of COVID-19 advisers has said multiplying the daily case count by 10 would give a more accurate picture.â See Governments of Canada as well as Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220521170744/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220521170024/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-presence-of-ba220-in-ontario-doesnt-warrant-significant-concern/

On 30 may 2022, the policy ideal of some jurisdictions continues to   be to supplement polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of symptomatic cases with mass availability of lateral flow rapid tests to asymptomatic individuals. However, in most parts of Canada, the caseload wave is frustrating efforts to achieve testing aspirations. In Canadaâs most populous province of Ontario: âDue to testing limitations, officials say the actual number of daily new cases is likely far higher than the figure reported.â See Governments of Canada as well as CBC news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220529161107/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220529160646/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/toronto/ontario-covid-update-saturday-may-28-2022-1.6469644

On 6 june 2022, the policy ideal of some jurisdictions continues to be to supplement polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing of symptomatic cases with mass availability of lateral flow rapid tests to asymptomatic individuals. However, in most parts of Canada, the caseload wave is frustrating efforts to achieve testing aspirations. E.g., according to a recent media report: ârapid antigen tests have replaced wide-scale PCR tests; fewer people are now eligible for PCR testing across the country after high demand for testing during the Omicron wave overwhelmed testing centresâ¦an infectious disease physician at the University of Alberta Hospital in Edmonton, saidâ¦ "the public does not have a way of being able to confirm they actually have COVID â¦â she noted that rapid tests have become less reliable when it comes to Omicronâ. See Governments of Canada as well as CBC news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220605105043/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220603140724/https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/rapid-test-cease-2022-phac-1.6475870

On 9 may 2022, government of Canada advises that when individuals âtest positive for COVID-19, a public health official will ask you questions to collect important information about your symptoms; activities and travel you did before you tested positive; all the people you may have been in close contact with while you were contagious ...contact tracing. It's a key public health measure.â Most provinces and territories intend to follow this practice, if conditions and resources permit. However, tracing capacity is not sufficient in most jurisdictions to deal with high case numbers. In most cases, contact tracing responsibility is up to individuals who are symptomatic and/or have tested positive. In Canadaâs most populous province, Ontario: âIf you have symptoms of COVID-19 or have tested positive, tell your close contacts that they have been exposedâ¦ Informing your contact will help stop the spread of the virus. Give them the link to this webpage, ontario.ca/exposed, so they can protect themselves and their contacts.â See Governments of Canada and Ontario websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220508140846/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/2019-novel-coronavirus-infection/symptoms/testing.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220510005015/https://covid-19.ontario.ca/exposed

On 9 may 2022: âQuebec is lifting most indoor mask mandates this week.  It's the final week that masks will be mandatory in many spots in Quebec as that province is ending most of its masking rules on Saturday (the 14th).â Quebecâs mask mandate for those in indoor public spaces, exempts students in classrooms. Some other jurisdictions also require masks in specific environments â e.g., public transit, health care facilities. See CBC and Toronto Star news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220510015535/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/ottawa/covid19-ottawa-coronavirus-symptoms-information-may-9-2022-1.6445626  https://web.archive.org/web/20220508142215/https://www.thestar.com/news/canada/2022/05/04/cp-newsalert-quebec-to-end-mask-mandate-may-14-last-province-to-remove-health-order.html

On 14 may 2022: âQuebec â¦ became the last province to allow residents to go maskless in most indoor public placesâ¦allowing patrons of stores, bars, restaurants, gyms and shopping centres, along with students in elementary and high schools, to wear a mask only if they choose to. Masking remains mandatory, however, on public transit and in health-care facilities. People who contract COVID-19 will have to wear a mask in public while they recoverâ. Because Quebecâs former masking rule did not cover all public spaces â e.g., exempted those in school classrooms, no change in code from 2T. Some other jurisdictions also require masks in specific environments â e.g., public transit, health care facilities. See Globe and Mail newspaper website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220514164054/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/canada/article-quebec-becomes-last-province-to-lift-covid-19-masking-health-order/

On 16 may 2022 in Prince Edward Island (PEI): âmasking is required in certain high risk settings, including hospitals, long term care, community care, public transit, early learning and childcare, and students and staff in K-12 when they are on buses and when not seated in class.â Some other jurisdictions also require masks in specific public spaces â e.g., public transit. See province of PEI and CBC news websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220516145945/https://www.princeedwardisland.ca/en/information/health-and-wellness/moving-on-transition-plan-to-living-with-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20220516152815/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/montreal/qc-mask-mandate-1.6450650

On 30 may 2022 in Prince Edward Island (PEI): âMasking is still required in certain high risk settings, including hospitals, long term care, community care and public transit.â Some other jurisdictions also require masks in specific public spaces â e.g., public transit. On 9 may 2022 11:21AM EDT, according to the CTV news unofficial vaccine tracker, 33,006,840 Canadians (86% of the total national population and 91% of the vaccine-eligible population aged 5+) have received at least one dose of an approved COVID-19 vaccine -- Moderna, Pfizer, Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen, AstraZeneca (no longer recommended), Novavax, Medicago Cofifenz. 31,306,676 Canadians (82% of total pop. and 86% of vax-eligible aged 5+) have received two doses. All provinces and territories are making vaccinations available to residents aged 5 and up. Provinces and territories are also delivering third doses. Third dose data have been revised with confirmation by Public Health Canada expected soon. Provinces and territories have started delivering fourth doses. (Note that vaccination data may not include Canadians who returned home after being vaccinated in other countries while wintering at retirement homes or on essential work trips. On the other hand, there may be a small amount of double-counting when residents live and work in different jurisdictions, vaccinations took place at work, and both jurisdictions count the vaccinations.) âFree vaccines will be available to everyone in Canada.â See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220507102339/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/vaccines.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220501140559/https://health-infobase.canada.ca/covid-19/vaccination-coverage/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220424222620/https://www.canada.ca/content/dam/phac-aspc/documents/services/immunization/national-advisory-committee-on-immunization-naci/naci-summary-april-12-2022.pdf

On 16 may 2022, the vaccine-eligible population continues to be aged 5+. Approved COVID-19 vaccines: Moderna, Pfizer, Johnson & Johnson (J&J) Janssen, AstraZeneca (no longer recommended), Novavax, Medicago Cofifenz. Provinces and territories are also delivering third doses and have started delivering fourth doses. âFree vaccines will be available to everyone in Canada.â See government of Canada website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220515162823/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/vaccines.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20220515163212/https://health-infobase.canada.ca/covid-19/vaccination-coverage/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220424222620/https://www.canada.ca/content/dam/phac-aspc/documents/services/immunization/national-advisory-committee-on-immunization-naci/naci-summary-april-12-2022.pdf

On 9 may 2022, in Newfoundland and Labrador (NL): âTemporary restrictions to visitation/attendance are in place at all provincially operated acute care facilities, treatment facilities, health centres and long-term care homes; as well as privately operated long-term care homes, personal care homes, and community care homesâ¦ Each patient/resident can have up to two visitors at a timeâ. NL may be the last Canadian jurisdiction with 2 = narrow restrictions in place regardless of visitor vaccination status. In British Columbia (BC): âThere are no capacity restrictions on visitors at long-term care and seniors' assisted living facilitiesâ¦ All visitors must show proof of vaccination before visiting a long-term care or seniors' assisted-living facility.â See governments of BC and NL websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220510020130/https://www.gov.nl.ca/covid-19/life-during-covid-19/health-facilities/overall-guidance/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220509215623/www2.gov.bc.ca/gov/content/covid-19/info/restrictions

New York:   The isolation period for K-12 students with a positive COVID-19 test result has been shortened to five day from ten days.  Quarantine due to exposure to COVID-19 has also been shortened; "If your child is NOT fully vaccinated and was exposed to COVID-19 outside of a school setting, your child must quarantine for at least 5 days; this is reduced from 10 days. If your child is fully vaccinated and was exposed outside of school, your child can continue to attend school so long as they do not have any symptoms."   All students and staff must wear a face covering when riding on school buses and indoors regardless of vaccination status, unless they have a medical exemption.     Additionally, face coverings are optional on school grounds for students in kindergarten through grade 12 since Monday, March 7. The indoor mask mandate is still active for LYFE, EarlyLearn (Infants & Toddlers), 3-K, Pre-K, and 4410 classrooms. Children two years old and older, and all staff in these classrooms, must continue to wear a face covering indoors. Since children under the age of five are not yet eligible to receive the vaccine, face coverings remain our strongest defense against COVID-19 for our youngest learners.    For more information, see archive:   https://archive.ph/rbXT0

California:   No change.  State-wide:  "Physical distancing and capacity limits for businesses and activities are over. Guidance for specific industries has ended. But employers are still responsible for maintaining safe environments for employees and customers."  There are still official "COVID-19 Prevention Emergency Temporary Standards" in place.    Sources:    https://web.archive.org/web/20220522005046/https://covid19.ca.gov/workers-and-businesses/    New York:   Certain workers in New York City, like educators, who perform in-person work or interact with the public in the course of business must show proof that they have received a COVID-19 vaccine.      See archive:   https://archive.ph/DQnPX

There is no requirement of public events cancellation under state-level order.   Risk-based guidance are in place. Private gatherings are not recommended for high-risk individuals.   Source: Austintexas.gov  Archive: https://web.archive.org/web/20220521082308/https://www.austintexas.gov/page/special-events-updates-covid-19
